class_notes: (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) The Human and the Divine: This class examines the relationship between knowledge and the divine; it thus looks both at evidence for the existence or non-existence of the divine and at the epistemological implications of this. Toward this end, we will read a number of authors, ranging from the Classical Period, through the Medieval era, and into our contemporary epoch, including Plato, Aristotle, Augustine, Boethius, Ibn Sina, Ibn Rushd, Aquinas, Descartes, Nietzsche, and Sartre. Through this, students will attain a historically informed perspective of our present-day understanding of knowledge, together with the relation between this, the divine, and the role of evidence.
course_description: Study and analysis of the thought of one major philosopher or the study of a special problem or set of related problems in philosophy.
sections: Class Nbr: This section is full 3353, Section #: 1, Type: SEM, Campus: ATL, Meets: MW 9:40-10:55a, Instructor: J. Bell, Status: Closed
